Award.AwardTitle: OP: Enabling High-Temperature Photonic Technologies with Plasmonic Ceramics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description: Plasmonics has demonstrated a unique capability to bridge photonics and electronics and enable nanoscale devices for applications in imaging, sensing, data storage, and light harvesting that are efficient, compact, and multifunctional. However most of the demonstrated plasmonic systems fall short in meeting the unique challenges of harsh environments, particularly high temperatures, faced by chemical and oil/gas industries, aerospace, defense, etc. This project aims to discover and realize robust, ultra-compact, chip-compatible, nanoscale optical devices using plasmonic ceramic materials that operate at high temperatures and exhibit high durability. This interdisciplinary effort is expected to have a significant impact both in the fundamental science of optics and optical materials as well as in optical, terahertz and microwave technologies and to generate significant industry interest and start-up possibilities. Integrated in this project are student education, outreach activities, and the development of materials illustrating the unique properties of plasmonic materials and devices. Specifically, the research team develops an online "book" on refractory ceramics that would provide temperature dependence of the optical properties, as well as fabrication protocol and major applications. An online "book," a learning module, simulation tools and tutorials are created and made available to the global nanophotonics research and educational community via nanoHUB.org.

Technical Description: Plasmonic structures have been historically designed in the physics and electrical engineering communities based on room-temperature experimental data and the corresponding phenomenological models of bulk noble metals at room temperature. This project is designed to overcome application-specific drawbacks associated with the use of metals as building blocks of nanoscale functional plasmonic devices by replacing metals with robust, refractory plasmonic ceramic materials, particularly transition metal nitrides (TiN, ZrN, and HfN). The properties of these materials at high temperatures and their usage for plasmonic devices for applications under extreme environments are studied experimentally and via numerical simulations. The research subjects include investigation of optical properties of transition metal nitrides, in both thin-film and nanostructured forms; high-temperature stability and metal-dielectric phase transitions; and surface/interface phenomena of composites. In addition, an online handbook of refractory plasmonic ceramics is created to benefit the nanophotonics research and educational community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to their unique ability to confine light down to the nanometer scale, plasmonic nanostructures have been widely investigated for their applications in subwavelength sensing, imaging, energy conversion, photocatalysis, and on-chip photonic circuitry. However, the development of practical plasmonic devices requiring operation in harsh environments, such as high temperatures, has been impeded due to a limited selection of materials predominantly consisting of soft metals such as gold and silver. We have studied the evolution of the optical and structural properties at high temperatures of various plasmonic materials, including silver, gold and plasmonic titanium nitride. We identified titanium nitride and other transition metal nitrides (TMNs) as a promising material platform for the design of practical plasmonic devices operating at elevated temperatures due to their refractory nature and significantly higher durability in harsh environments compared to noble metals. Our developed temperature-dependent numerical models for the TMN’s dielectric permittivity are crucial for proper design of plasmonic devices for high temperature sensors, light harvesting, energy conversion, and heat-assisted applications. We applied our findings to numerically demonstrate a resonant metasurface with a temperature dependent reflectance for high temperature sensing using titanium nitride. This approach may enable real-time measurements in a wide range of harsh environment applications from high temperature drilling operations to turbine engines. 

In addition to the high-temperature investigations of titanium nitride, we have also optimized unique approaches for fabricating plasmonic titanium nitride nanostructures over large areas. We demonstrated that titanium dioxide can be nitridized to achieve plasmonic titanium nitride thin films, nanoparticles and nanowires at a large scale that is difficult to achieve with standard deposition and lithographic techniques. We have also demonstrated the spontaneous formation of titanium nitride nanoparticles using layer by layer assembly to fabricate a high efficiency broadband absorber. These methods can be easily utilized for large scale fabrication over macroscopic areas on a wide range of substrates, including conformal surfaces.

Finally, we have studied the properties of atomically thin titanium nitride. Atomically thin metallic films, or transdimensional plasmonic materials, have received wide interest for investigating novel quantum phenomena and providing uniquely strong light confinement. More importantly, metallic films with thicknesses of just a few atomic layers are predicted to show unprecedented tunability of their electronic and optical properties, which has been difficult to achieve accomplish at visible wavelengths.  We have successfully grown metallic titanium nitride films down to thicknesses of 1 nm (5 atomic layers) allowing us access to the extremely tunable optical properties necessary to achieve actively tunable nanophotonic devices. Our experimental demonstrations establish transdimensional plasmonic materials as an attractive material platform for dynamically switchable and tailorable plasmonic devices at visible wavelengths.
